title: 109_s3719
content: The "Renewable Schools Energy Act of 2006" is cited as the short title. It introduces qualified renewable school energy bonds under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Renewable Schools Energy Act of 2006" introduces qualified renewable school energy bonds under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Taxpayers holding these bonds can receive a credit against their tax equal to 25 percent of the annual credit determined for the bond. The credit rate is determined by the Secretary. The Secretary determines a daily credit rate for qualified renewable school energy bonds to allow issuance without discount or interest cost to the issuer. The term 'credit allowance date' is defined for this purpose. The term 'credit allowance date' refers to specific dates throughout the year and includes the last day the bond is outstanding. A special rule applies for bonds issued or redeemed close to these dates, ensuring a prorated credit amount based on the period the bond is held. Additionally, there is a limitation on the credit amount based on the taxpayer's tax liability. The subsection (a) limits the tax credit for a taxable year based on the regular tax liability and other allowable credits. The term 'renewable school energy bond' is defined for qualified purposes related to eligible local education agencies. The subsection limits the tax credit for a taxable year based on regular tax liability and other allowable credits. A 'renewable school energy bond' must be issued by a State or local government of an eligible State for a qualified school, with a 20-year term. A qualified school is defined as a public school or public school system administrative building owned or operated by an eligible local education agency. The term 'eligible local education agency' refers to any local educational agency defined in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The term 'eligible State' pertains to states with significant population growth and specific demographic criteria. The term 'qualified purpose' is also defined within the context of the text. The term 'qualified purpose' in relation to qualified schools refers to the purchase and installation of renewable energy products. There is a national renewable school energy bond limitation for each calendar year, starting at $50,000,000 in 2007 and increasing to $100,000,000 in 2008 and $150,000,000 in 2009. The allocation of this limitation is determined by the Secretary among eligible States based on population growth percentages. The limitation amount allocated to eligible States is based on population growth percentages, with the greatest percentage going to the second and third ranked States, 10 percent to the fourth and fifth ranked States, and 10 percent to a specific State. This amount is then allocated by the State education agency to qualified schools within the State, with a maximum limit on the bonds that can be issued for each school in a calendar year. Unused limitations can be carried over to the following year. The limitation amount for eligible States can be carried over to the following year if not fully utilized, with a maximum of two years for carryforward. The term 'bond' includes any obligation, and 'State' includes the District of. The term 'State' includes the District of Columbia and any possession of the United States. Gross income includes the amount of the credit allowed to the taxpayer under this section. Regulations allow for the separation of ownership of a qualified renewable school energy bond and the entitlement to the credit. In the case of a separation of ownership of a qualified renewable school energy bond and the entitlement to the credit, certain rules apply. The credit allowed by this section is treated as a nonrefundable bondholder credit. Special rules similar to those under section 54(l) apply. Conforming amendments are made to the table of sections. The amendments made by this section apply to bonds issued after December 31, 2006.
